summary.seg: Emmanuel College, MS 59 contains a copy of the Dioptra ('Mirror'), an ascetic work in poetry, originally composed by a monk known as Philip Monotropos (meaning 'solitary') (ca. 1100 CE). The work enjoyed great popularity in the 14th century, when it was reworked by a certain Phialites; this manuscript dates to that period. (On the Dioptra see, among others, Grumel, 'Remarques sur la Dioptra de Philippe le Solitaire', Byzantinische Zeitschrift 44 (1951), 198-211; Kazhdan, 'Philip Monotropos', in The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium (Oxford, 1991); Afentoulidou-Leitgeb, 'Die "Dioptra" des Philippos Monotropos', Byzantion 77 (2007), 9-31 ).

Under the common title of Dioptra in this manuscript, as in most of the exemplars of the later tradition, there are contained two works by Philip Monotropos: the Dioptra itself, composed in 1095, containing verses of lament directed to one's own soul, and the Dialexis, a dialogue between the soul and the flesh.

Emmanuel MS 59 is not dated, but is datable to the 14th century on the basis of the script and of its paper. The scribe made a lot of errors while copying the text, which seem to suggest that he had difficulties reading the script of his exemplar. The codex has suffered damage: it has been rebound, and the current structure does not reflect its original state, with some leaves having been bound in out of order.

msItem.author: Philippus Solitarius
msItem.title: Dioptra
msItem.note: The manuscript contains the Dioptra in the Y-version ( E. Afentoulidou-Leitgeb, 'Die "Dioptra" des Philippos Monotropos und ihr Kontext. Ein Beitrag zur Rezeptionsgeschichte', Byzantion 77, (2007), 9-31 (p. 31)), with a series of annexed texts (see Afentoulidou-Leitgeb and, for a list of the texts in Emmanuel MS 59, p. 31)

msItem.title: Klauthmoi
Laments
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Μετρικὴ ὑπόθεσις καὶ ὑπόμνησις διὰ στιχοπλοκίας πῶς ἡ ψυχὴ τοῦ σώματος διαζεύγνυται καὶ ποῦ τυγχάνῃ ἄχρι τῆς κοινῆς ἀναστάσεως· καὶ ὅτι οὐ πατὴρ οὐ μήτηρ οὐ τέκνα οὐ συγγενεῖς οὐ φίλοι ἐν ἐκείνῃ τῇ ὥρᾳ δύνανται αὐτῇ βοηθεῖσαι εἰ μὴ τὰ ἔργα αὐτῆς καὶ μόνα· καὶ τίνες αὐτὴν παραλαμβάνουσι καὶ ποῦ μετὰ χωρισμὸν καθίστησιν αὐτὴν καὶ ποῖα κρίσις αὐτῇ μετὰ τὴν ἀνάστασιν γένηται καὶ πόσοι κλαυθμοὶ καὶ θρῆνοι· Ἰωάννου μοναχοῦ ἁμαρτωλοῦ καὶ ξένου, δι’ ὧν καὶ ἀπελέγετο πρὸς τὴν ἰδίαν ψυχὴν. Στίχοι τη΄
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Πῶς κάθῃ, πῶς ἀμεριμνεῖς, πῶς ἀμελεῖς, ψυχή μου
msItem.explicit: f. 7v ἀμὴν ἀμὴν καὶ γένοιτο, γένοιτο, γένοιτό μοι.
msItem.note: The text of the Klauthmoi is preceded on f. 1r ll. 1-13 by a table of contents written in red ink, comprising also the first two lines of the text ( Les pleurs de Philippe. Poëme en vers politiques de Philippe le Solitaire, ed. by E. Auvry (Paris, 1875), p. 18; see also S. Lavriotes, Ἡ Διόπτρα, in: Ὁ Ἄθως (1920), 1 [repr. in G.M. Prochorov, A.B. Bil’djug, H. Miklas, "Dioptra" Filippa Monotropa. Antropologičeskaja enciklopedija pravoslavnogo srednevekov’ja (Moscow, 2008), pp. 331-504], where this text is indicated as logos 5 of the Dioptra)

From this manuscript was printed an edition of the text of the Klauthmoi: E.S. Shuckburgh, The Soul and the Body. A Medieval Greek Poem printed for the first time from a ms. in the Emmanuel College Library (Cambridge, 1894)

msItem.title: Dialexis, 1
msItem.incipit: f. 8r l. 27 Πολλοὺς μὲν ἔχομεν ὁμοῦ καὶ χρόνους καὶ καιρούς τε
msItem.explicit: f. 34v l. 18 νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ πάντοτε εἰς αἰῶνας αἰώνων.
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a list of the chapters on f. 8r ll. 1-26, tit. Ἃ δὲ ἐστὶν ἐν τῷ δευτέρῳ λόγῳ, σαφὲς ἡ ἀπόδειξης τούτων

The book is numbered 2 in the manuscript; the beginning is partially different from the printed text; after f. 34r l. 29 ( Lavriotes 2008, p. 366 v. 1568) the text does not correspond to the printed edition
In the lower margin the scribe wrote in red ink the number of verses

msItem.title: Dialexis, 2
msItem.rubric: f. 35v l. 19 Ὁ λόγος περιέχων στίχους χιλίους ἑξακοσίους νδ΄
msItem.incipit: f. 35v l. 13 Ἰδοὺ καὶ ἄλλο ζήτημα, ἰδοὺ καὶ τέρα πεύσης
msItem.explicit: f. 65r l. 1 νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ πάντοτε εἰς πάντας τοὺς αἰῶνας
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a list of the chapters on ff. 34v l. 19-35v l. 10, tit. Τάδε ἔστιν ἐν τῷ τρίτῳ λόγῳ

Leaves are now in disorder; the text follows this sequence: ff. 34v-36v, 40r-40v, 48r-48v, 41r-43v, 45r-45v, 44r-44v, 46r-47v, 49r-64v, 38r-39v, 65r; the text ends, before the closing formula on f. 65r l. 1, at f. 39v l. 28 at Lavriotes 2008, p. 415, v. 1562
Some passages present in the printed edition are omitted in the mauscript, as, Lavriotes (2008), p. 408 v. 1529-414
The logos is numbered 3 in the manuscript

msItem.title: Dialexis, 3
msItem.incipit: f. 65r Θεράπενα προείρηκας ἐν τῷ λόγῳ τῷ τρίτῳ
msItem.explicit: f. 89r l. 9 ἀμὴν ἀμὴν γένοιτο γένοιτό μοι
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a list of the chapters on f. 65r ll. 2-20, tit. Ὁ λόγος νῦν ὁ τέταρτος ἐνταῦθα νῦν παρέστι
Leaves are now in disorder; the text follows this order: ff. 65r-70v, 37r-37v, 71r-89r
The book is numbered 4 in the manuscript

msItem.title: Dialexis, 4
msItem.incipit: f. 89v Τί δήποτε θεράπενα τὰς λογικὰς δυνάμεις
msItem.explicit: f. 153v l. 18 δόξα κυρίῳ τῷ θεῷ πάντοτε εἰς αἰῶνας
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a list of the chapters on ff. 89r l. 10-89v l. 17, tit. Τάδε ἐστὶ καὶ ἐν τῷ πέμπτῳ λὀγῳ

The text does not always correspond to the printed one, there are passages omitted, as Lavriotes 2008, pp. 483 l, 18-485 l. 11, and pp. 487-491 (ch. 10), and the order of some chapters is different; after f. 137r l. 19 ( Lavriotes 2008, p. 496, the end of logos 4 in the printed edition), texts follow, whithout interruption, which are not present in the printed edition, but which recur in the manuscripts of the Dioptra (on this matter see Afentoulidou-Leitgeb 2007):
ff. 137r l. 19-138r l. 6, inc. Πέντε γὰρ εἰσὶν ἐργασίαι δι' ὧν ο θεὸς θεραπεύεται (see Afentoulidou-Leitgeb 2007, p. 16)
f. 138r ll. 6-14, inc. Τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου. Παντὶ τῷ αἰτοῦντι σε δίδου
ff. 138r l. 14-139v l. 6, inc. Τοῦ αὐτοῦ. Οὐ δύνασε νηστεῦσαι
ff. 139v l. 7-140v l. 10, inc. Ἐκ τῶν ἀσκητικῶν τοῦ μεγάλου Βασιλείου. Τοῖς μὲν οὖν συγκενεῦσιν
f. 140v ll. 10-26, inc. Ἐκ τοῦ Κλίμακος περὶ τὴν ἄσκησιν ἀθετῶν
ff. 140v l. 27-153v l. 18, inc. Στίχοι ἐπὶ τελευτὴν θρηνητικοί, this is a still umpublished text by Philippos Monotropos, see Afentoulidou-Leitgeb (2007), p. 23 and note 33)
The book is numbered 5 in the manuscript

msItem.title: In ramos palmarum, recensio longior
msItem.rubric: f. 153v Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου λόγος εἰς τὰ βαία
msItem.incipit: f. 153v l. 19 Ἤδη τῆς δεσποτικῆς πανηγύρεως παρακύπτει τὰ χαρίσματα
msItem.explicit: f. 158v καὶ τὰς κάτω δυνάμεις μὴ ὑπο
msItem.note: Ιn the manuscript the text is attributed to John Chrysostom, Saint, -407 John Chrysostom (d. 407) , but it is spurious: the author is Leontius, Presbyter of Constantinople
The text ends imperfectly due to the loss of leaves, at P. Allen, C. Datema, Leontii presbyteri Constantinopolitani homiliae (Turnhout, 1987), p. 176 l. 269

support.material: ff. 1-158 Western paper à grosse vergeure, folded in quarto. Watermarks: ff. 1-158 Bell ( ca. 55/60 32 ) in the gutter, comparable to the types Briquet Cloche 3933, 3935, 3936 which are dated in 1342-1348, 1346-1355, and 1347. The watermarks in the form of a Bell on paper with thick laid lines were used in the years 1350-1382 ca.

ff. i-iii, 159 Later endleaves. Western paper, folded in quarto; the paper of f. 259 is not the same of ff. i-iii. Watermarks: f. i Coat of arms with a shield on which there are three X flanked by two rampant lions ( ca. 70 ca. 25 ) in the gutter only the lower part is visible, but it is the type Heawood Coat of arms . 342-437 , which was in use ca. between the last quarter of the 17th c. and the first quarter of the 18th.

foliation.p: Foliation in Arabic numerals, in ink, in the upper margin, right, from 1 to 158; where the numbers have been lost to trimming, modern additions have been written in pencil; three later endleaves at the beginning have been foliated in pencil from i to iii, and an endleaf at the end of the manuscript has been numbered in pencil as 159; six leaves which came with the restoration of the binding, are unnumbered (ff. [a]-[f]): [a]-[c] + i-iii + 1-159 + [d]-[f].

collation.p: The leaves, particularly those at the end of the manuscript, have been restored with paper strips pasted along the inner part, near the gutter, therefore it is hard to reconstruct the original collation, considering also that the quires do not show original signatures; leaves 32-71 are today out of order, testifying that the original bifolia and quires are not in their original state; the collation proposed by M.R. James in his catalogue (18-1, 28-188, 196, 206, 214) does not consider this and does not always match with the position of the watermark. The quires have been sewn very tightly, therefore it is not possible to see clearly the present arrangement of the quires.
collation.signatures: The quires have been numbered from 1 to 21 in pencil, in the lower margin, right; this numbering corresponds to the collation proposed by James in the catalogue, but it does not represent the original structure of the manuscript.

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is in fair condition. There are humidity and some brown stains throughout, but the text is always redeable. The first and last leaves, which were damaged, have been repaired also by integrating tears with paper strips. Worm holes throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: A single column of 28-30 lines, mostly 28. ca. 155 ca. 95

handNote.p: ff. 1r-158v Hand A: the text was written entirely in a minuscule script, vertical, regular in size, which can be compared to the scripts pertaining to the so-called Metochitesstil.
The text is written in black ink, titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote:
Friezes in red and black ink are present throughout the manuscript, at the beginning of text and books:
f. 1r plaited ornament in red ink
f. 8r a ribbon curled around a rod in red ink
ff. 34v, 65r rectangular friezes filled with various ornaments
ff. 89r, 153v rope ornament on a black background
f. 136r udulated linear frieze in black ink with clovers at both ends coloured in red
Thick minor initials in red ink are present throughout, at the beginning of each verse of the poem (see e.g. ff. 54v-55r).

additions.p: On the left pastedown are written the present and previous shelfmarks in pencil MS 59 (I.3.6).

On the later endleaves (17th/18th. century) ff. i recto, iii recto, iii verso, there are notes by a later hand; on f. i there are notes in Latin about Philippos Monotropos and his work: since Bernard de Monrfaucon's Palaeographia Graeca of 1708 is mentioned, this date constitutes a terminus post quem for this intervention. On ff. iii recto-iii verso there is a transcription of ff. 1r-1v by a western European hand; in the upper margin, by a different hand than the one which wrote the notes in Latin on f. i recto, is written the name of Hugo Broughton D. (see History).
On f. 159r a later hand (16th c.?) wrote a list of titles numbered from α΄ (1) to κη΄ (28). On f. 159v there are random notes in Greek ( Probationes calami) and a note in Hebrew.

binding.p: Early modern western binding, leather cover over couched-laminate boards. Blind tooling on both covers, with a bird (eagle?) in the centre and a decorated rectangular frame around it. The stamp is very similar to one used in Cambridge in the early 17th century (see Bindings in Cambridge Libraries, with notes by G.D. Hobson, based on researches by N.F. Barwell, H.M. Davies, C. E. Sayle (Cambridge, 1929), plate XLI, tool no. 39). Blind tooling on the edges. 205 140 48
binding.condition: Rebacked. The manuscript is preserved in a box with three envelopes containing three labels, originally pasted on the spine, with the previous shelfmark, MSS, 1, 3, 6; tanned leather sewing supports; a tanned leather endcap.

origin.p: The manuscript was probably copied in the 14th century; since the paper is a type which was used c. 1350-1382, the production of the manuscript can be placed in the second half of the century.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated by Broughton, Hugh, 1549-1612 Hugh Broughton (1549-1612) , divine and Hebraist who studied in Cambridge and was fellow of St John's College and Christ's College, as written in a note in the upper margin of f. iii recto, Hugo Broughton donavit . On f. [a] recto is pasted the Emmanuel College bookplate.

recordHist.source: Description (2021) draws partly on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Emmanuel College (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1904), pp. 52-53

availability.p: Visitors to Emmanuel College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Emmanuel College: Special Collections.
